name: Honeycomb theorem
rephrased: A regular hexagonal grid has the least perimeter for any equal-area division of the plane.
implication_form: If all regions in a plane subdivision have the same area, then the arrangement with the smallest total perimeter is a regular hexagonal grid.
explained: The Honeycomb Theorem states that among all subdivisions of the plane into regions of equal area, the regular hexagonal grid (such as that found in a honeycomb) has the minimal total perimeter. This means that any other subdivision into cells of the same area will have a greater total perimeter length than the hexagonal grid.
related_conjectures: Kelvin Problem (minimal surface area for bubbles)
